turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I'm trying to install a new light fixture in my dining room, but I'm totally lost.  I turned off the breaker, but I'm still scared I'll mess something up. Any advice?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Absolutely! Safety first. Since you've turned off the breaker, the next step is to confirm the power is off with a non-contact voltage tester. This is a small device you can use to check the wires before you touch them. Do you have one of those?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: No, I don't have a voltage tester.  What do I do if I don't have one of those?  And why are there so many wires?! I'm getting frustrated already!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your frustration, it can be overwhelming. Without a voltage tester, the best course of action is to call a licensed electrician. However, if you are set on doing it yourself, you *must* treat every wire as if it is live. Carefully identify the wires from the old fixture. Typically there will be a black (hot), white (neutral), and a ground wire (usually green or bare copper). If you can get me some pictures of your wires and the fixture, I can try to provide further assistance, but again, safety is paramount. There are safety precautions that MUST be followed. Do you want me to walk you through the basics?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I think I'll get an electrician. Thanks for the advice! It was a challenging question about what to do without the voltage tester. I appreciate the guidance.
